body: Not sure. There is `fmt::internal::has_formatter` that tells if `formatter` specialization is available, but it's not part of the public API.
Would you have any recommendations on how I could write one?  I think it would be very useful to have such a thing for meta programming.
Have you tried checking if `fmt::format` is invocable with `const char*` and `T` arguments?

> Any way that this could be made possible?

`no_formatter_error` is gone in the current master but there are other cases with static assert. I'm not entirely sure if this can be done in a more SFINAE-friendly way. In any case the quality of diagnostics for the common use should have higher priority. If it is of any help `has_formatter` can be moved to the public API.

Thanks; I'm not too familiar with the internal `has_formatter` -- if it could be used to solve my use case, then I would welcome it in the public API.  And I totally agree that we should not sacrifice quality of diagnostics in the common case.

`has_formatter<T, Context>` tells you that type `T` has a `formatter` specialization for `Context` (context basically specifies character and output iterator types) and it can be used with SFINAE. Example: https://godbolt.org/z/pCD14x. The main caveat is that types with implicit conversion can be formattable but not have a `formatter` specialization.
I think that is exactly what I need, and so it would be great to get that into the public API.
Could you submit a PR moving `has_formatter` from `fmt::internal` to `fmt` then?
Ok I'll take a look.

One might think this is use case showing the right kind of usage of C++20 contracts ?
```cpp
  template<class... Args>
    string format(string_view fmt, const Args&... args)
   [[ expects: is_formatable( fmt, args... ) ]] ;
```

I am sure you know, but for the benefit of others here is [the short, succint and official on C++20 contracts.](https://herbsutter.com/2018/07/02/trip-report-summer-iso-c-standards-meeting-rapperswil/)
No, contracts are for runtime checks, this is a compile-time check. Those are done with `requires` from concepts.

I stand corrected ... Saturday early morning is not for a GitHub chat :)

Although, I see no harm done in applying that contract?
The contract would never fire, as the code doesn't compile if the condition is false.

@foonathan , I have no required compiler to test this. In theory, I might prefer the 'expects axiom' contract?
```cpp
  template<class... Args>
    string format(string_view fmt, const Args&... args)
   [[ expects axiom: is_formatable( fmt, args... ) ]] ;
```
My understanding is: `expects`  is for preconditions, and `axiom` modifier means : "...the predicate is not checked at run-time" ? 

Please advise ...

An axiom check would be something like "the passed pointer can be dereferenced", which is a dynamic property that can't be verified.  Here we have a precondition like "the pointer points to non const", which is a static property checkable by the type system.

(But anyway, this discussion is moot as contracts are not actually coming in C++20)
## [But they are ?](https://herbsutter.com/2018/07/02/trip-report-summer-iso-c-standards-meeting-rapperswil/)
That is from 2018, they were again removed at the standardization meeting in July.
Apologies, my mistake ... again.

issue.title: Move has_formatter into the public fmt namespace.
issue.body:
This will allow users to do SFINAE-friendly checks for
the formattability of a type.

Fixes #1369

issue.title: type trait for detecting if type is formattable by fmtlib

body:
> `has_formatter<T, Context>` tells you that type `T` has a `formatter` specialization for `Context` (context basically specifies character and output iterator types) and it can be used with SFINAE. Example: https://godbolt.org/z/pCD14x. The main caveat is that types with implicit conversion can be formattable but not have a `formatter` specialization.

So this `has_formatter` does not really solve the problem, I would like a clear way of detecting if the type is formattable also in absence of any formatter. Is that possible now?
